properties.description:
You may have heard of Shakespeare's timeless works, or Homer's Iliad, but you may be less familiar with their Persian equal (some would even say, superior), the Shahnama. The "Book of Kings" is a treasured piece of Persian literature written by Iranian poet Firdawsi during the 10th century CE. It reflects the history of Iran, from the beginning of the world -- as can be seen in the story of Gayrumars -- up until the loss of Persian independence to the Arab conquest in the 7th century CE (Farhat-Holzman, 2001, 3). As an epic poem, the Shahnama calls back to the rich history of passing down heroic tales through the generations by word of mouth alone, for there had been no real need of written language until the rapid expansion of the Persian empire in the 6th century CE (Farhat-Holzman, 2001, 2).

Our particular manuscript is one of the three elaborately illustrated copies of the Shahnama, made for the three grandsons of the House of Timur -- Baysunghur, Muhammad Juki, and Ibrahim Sultan. This copy of the manuscript was dedicated to Ibrahim Sultan, believed to originate in Shiraz, Iran, between 1420 and 1440, during which he ruled over the area as governor (Sims, 1992, 6).

This manuscript is now held in the Bodleian Library in Oxford University, England. The digital copy of this manuscript is available as public domain on the library's website, so anyone (with access to good internet service) may experience Firdawsi's Shahnama in both its vivid poetic verse and elaborate illustrations. It is from here that I have retrieved the given image, folio 216b, illustrating an episode called "Kay Khusrow kills Aila".

This folio depicts an intense battle. Two hosts of soldiers taking up arms against each other, one partially hidden behind a hill, the other somewhat obscured by a large cloud of dust left by charging horses. At the centre of the image is a man dressed in dark clothing with elaborate golden designs. This gives the effect of elevated status and wealth, as the golden design seems to blossom over his chest and shoulders like an enchanted flower. Here, it functions like a crown would, marking Kay Khusrow, Shah of Iran. This also stays true to the text, which places the Shah at the centre of the battle.

Before we dive deeper into the image, however, we must first briefly discuss the question itching everyone's mind: how did we get there?

The event of this folio is a continuation of the much anticipated Great War between Kay Khusrow of Iran, and Afrasiyab of Turan (his maternal grandfather), as Kay Khusrow pledge vengeance on Afrasiyab for his father's murder. Shida, son of Afrasiyab, dies to Kay Khusrow in one-on-one combat, and the Turan leader and his soldiers, all overcome with grief and vengeance, meet Kay Khusrow and his Iranian army on the battlefield. It is after this that the episode of "Kay Khusrow kills Aila" takes place, where a fierce, bloody battle ensues for days on end.

Considering the title of this episode has the word "kill" in it, and we have already identified who Kay Khusrow is, it makes sense to first draw our attention to the body the Shah has driven his sword through. Khusrow's victim has fallen across his horse, and seems in the process of having the upper part of his body decapitated from the lower part. At this point, it is reasonable to infer this man is Aila, one of the many other kings and chiefs to join the long battle between Turan and Iran. His kill is given significance as, in the text, witnessing Kay Khusrow kill Aila right after he killed Ustukila (another king who joined Afrasiyab's forces against Iran) is what strikes fear into the hearts of the Turan soldiers after days of vengeful fighting. In fact, this sight prompts Garsiwaz, brother of Afrasiyab, to ask the Turan Shah to retreat, which of course Afrasiyab does not do. Not until his army chiefs steer his horse away themselves so they may take the night to recover themselves.

Despite the constant gory allusions to blood in the text, it is only for Aila's death that the artist chooses to show the red liquid as it bursts out of his body and stains the armour of his horse. The artist's choice here echoes the text description of "he burst his skin", and creates the effect of bloodshed involved in battle in a more concentrated way, perhaps to draw attention to this particular death. This resembles the image of an overstuffed bag being ripped open so that all its contents come tumbling out uncontrollably.

The text brings a lot of focus on the chaos taking over the battlefield, with particular attention to noise from drums and battle cries, as well as bloodshed that is so rampant, it draws fear into the Earth. The following excerpt from the story depicts this:
      The sun was darkened by the armies' dust,/n      While at the flashing spear-heads, eagle's plumes,
      The din of trumpets, shouting warriors,
      And heroes' maces on the battlefield,
      The crocodile in the water and the pard
      On land, the iron and the rocks and mountains,
      Dissolved with fear. Earth heaved and air was full
      Of shots; the wars of savage lions split;
      Thou wouldst have said: "The world is Ahriman's;
      'Tis naught but enemies from sleeve to skirt!"

Strangely enough, the artist has chosen to create the effect of chaos in battle in other ways, not focusing so much on noise or any limbs littering the field. Instead, we see flags and soldier heads painted outside of the gold boundaries of the page's margins. It feels like the soldiers are climbing out of the image, like bugs crawling out from under a box, disobeying the rules of boundaries in the frenzy of their fight. Additionally, the different colors of multiple flags in the air indicate the scale of the battle, as the text describes kings and chiefs from nearby regions joining the fight, including King Aila, who will later be killed by Kay Khusrow.

The use of the battle itself to depict chaos may be due in part to the preferences of Ibrahim Sultan. The Timurid princes sponsor art in a way similar to how they sponsored architecture, indicating their political attitudes. Hence, the illustrations in Ibrahim Sultan's Shahnama seem to focus on bazm u razm, the Iranian themes of hunting, feasting, and battle. (Sims, 1992, 5)

"...to the Cemeteries on the northwest. Every foot of the vast territory within these limits has been carefully examined and topographically drawn in perspective, by Mr. C. N. Dry and his assistants, and the faithfulness and accuracy with which this work has been done an examination of the pages will attest. Absolute truth and accuracy in the representation of the territory has been the standard and in no cases have additions or alterations been made unless the same were actually in course of construction. In a few cases, important public and private edifices that are not yet finished are shown completed, and as they will appear when done. All the buildings within the limits of the survey in July, 1875, are shown; and a very large number of those executed or commenced since that date have been also introduced, the pages having been constantly corrected up to the last possible moment before publication."

"In dividing the work into pages, it will be seen that in, cases where a building is but partially drawn on one page, it is given complete on the adjoining page. In view of the magnitude of the work, the originality of the idea, and the difficulties encountered in carrying it out, it is hoped that if any mistakes or errors have crept into the plates or pages, they will be looked upon with a lenient eye by an indulgent public." (Dry & Compton)
